poem:
### Little Girl, Big Emotions

At the field's edge,  
the tempest unfolds,  
a small storm with pigtails,  
voice lifting the din.

Adults, stunned, exchange  
clumsy advice like weather reports,  
but she's a cloudburst of self,  
raining unchecked.

In the chaos,  
each tear a raindrop,  
and she, a puddle,  
unexplained but present.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "No one wants to receive unsolicited parenting advice. But there’s one effective way to handle a child’s big emotions | Yumi Stynes I was at a kids’ soccer game and there were children everywhere. The environment was high-stress and even as an adult it was easy to feel overwhelmed just from being there. (Children in groups inexplicably scream.) Among the chaos was a little girl about three years old, crying and flailing on the floor". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
